Yes, there was a time when movies would be either R or PG. But because of the levels of adult material getting through in PG movies, they created a new category, PG-13, in order to better encapsulate that kind of content. Jurassic Park WASN'T released back then. It was released when PG-13 was a rating, and I would argue that it was rightly put into that category in terms of content, especially with the terror and gore they DO have in the movie.
Because it existed at the time where movies had PG-13 ratings, they aimed for that demographic. PG-13 doesn't usually mean Family Friendly. Tremors is a PG-13 horror film and I wouldn't characterize it as "kiddie" (which isn't a criticism lobbed specifically at you, but just from a general standpoint to those using that argument) I think is an intellectual cop-out of actual artistic criticism) or Family Friendly. Just because there are children in Jurassic Park as main characters and they don't violently die doesn't mean that it's a kid-friendly adventure, otherwise Aliens would be considered a Family Friendly film (Hell, I'd argue the kids in Jurassic Park get worse physical damage and terror than Newt in Aliens).
There are PG-13 films that I've felt had bigger impacts in terms of violence, sexuality, and other adult themes than R-rated fare without being explicit. In fact, when they're inhibited by how much content they can show, PG-13 movies can get more creative in terms of how it's executed.
Drag Me to Hell, The Dark Knight, The Others, The Ring, 10 Cloverfield Lane and Cloverfield are just some PG-13 movies that have some of the most horrifying moments I've ever seen on film without being explicit. It's also hard to argue that these films would be R or PG without the PG-13 rating because we don't know. Temple of Doom and Gremlins were rated PG at the time of their release, but public outcry demanded another level between those ratings, hence PG-13.
If we argued that if we remove every movie rating except "G," then every movie would be rated "G". So what? That doesn't remove the content in the movie, nor does it discredit what that film actually has inside of it. If Jurassic Park was made during the time of ONLY PG or R ratings, it would have to decide which side to air on in terms of content, but because they had a PG-13 rating, they were able to make a film with more extreme content than a PG movie, but still have broad appeal (which I would not characterize as inherently "family friendly")

To be fair, depending on how you define it, animation in mature/adult platforms is already THRIVING in the video game sphere. From the dedicated capturing of realistic motion in Splinter Cell: Chaos Theory, to simple animation design for clarity in Mark of the Ninja, to studio Ghibli designed artistic eccentricities with Ori and the Blind Forest, animation for adults is alive and well. Even things like Tales from the Borderlands, Life is Strange, Witcher: Wild Hunt, or Alien Isolation relies on traditional animation for their characters.
Adult animation in the west is a weird area of taboo. Thanks to South Park for starting the trend and Family Guy for solidifying it, adult animation has bursted through when attempting comedy (like with Chozen, Moonbeam City, Metalocalypse, Harvey Birdman, Archer, etc.). But for action/drama, there's still a bit of a hurdle. It's still difficult to get a straight up action-drama animated series FOR KIDS/FAMILIES. Thundercats (2011) was cancelled after one season, most of Cartoon Network and Disney's animated lineup is compromised on comedic series, more serious animated DC/Marvel shows like Young Justice or Spectacular Spider-man have been substituted for far more comedic fare with Justice League Action or Ultimate Spider-man. Hell, I'm impressed Legend of Korra made its way to the end of its run. I think there's also a bit of the early 90s resurgence of people over-policing the violence level for channels with action aimed towards kids, so it's just easier and more profitable to ignore it. It's even stranger once you look at the trend of live-action shows and movies incorporating more explicit adult elements like gore, sex, and swearing, yet animation has had the bar set even lower for what can and can't be shown.
